TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}
TEXT.source: ti Pułałułałuyan kati Tjukutjuku (Kułałau village, p.227)

S.FORM: izua ti Pułałułałuyan a se Łinasalas; saka izua ti Tjukutjuku a se Makalaulauz.
izoa ti Poljaljoljaljoyan a se Ljinasalas; saka izoa ti Tjokotjoko a se Makalaolaoz.
S.TRANSL: There was a person called Pułałułałuyan of Łinasalas, and also Tjukutjuku of Makalaulauz.

S.FORM: "ari, qałupi," aya tua sikataqałan; sa vaik a sema qemałup.
"ari, qaljopi," aya toa sikataqaljan; sa vaik a sema qemaljop.
S.TRANSL: “Come on, let’s go hunting,” said (Pułałułałuyan) to his fellow-villagers; and they went hunting.

S.FORM: manu izua kasiw a qatsaqatsa.
mano izoa kasiw a qacaqaca.
S.TRANSL: Now there was a tall tree,

S.FORM: manu łevavaw ti Pułałułałuyan.
mano ljevavaw ti Poljaljoljaljoyan.
S.TRANSL: and Pułałułałuyan climbed up it.

S.FORM: manu łengłengen ti Tjukutjuku, a pasa Makalaulauz.
mano ljengljengen ti Tjokotjoko, a pasa Makalaolaoz.
S.TRANSL: He saw Tjukutjuku over in Makalaulauz,

S.FORM: manu tjenglay ti Pułałułałuyan.
mano tjenglay ti Poljaljoljaljoyan.
S.TRANSL: and fell in love with her.

S.FORM: "ku kudavaw tsu," aya ti Pułałułałuyan; sa sikivułu tua quvał tu talayan.
"ko kodavaw co," aya ti Poljaljoljaljoyan; sa sikivoljo toa qovalj to talayan.
S.TRANSL: “What shall I do about this?” said Pułałułałuyan, and pulled out one of his hairs.

S.FORM: manu sipavali, sa djałun tjai Tjukutjuku.
mano sipavali, sa djaljon tjai Tjokotjoko.
S.TRANSL: It was carried by the wind all the way to Tjukutjuku,

S.FORM: manu sema tapułu.
mano sema tapoljo.
S.TRANSL: and went into her lap.

S.FORM: sa kavunglay ti Tjukutjuku.
sa kavonglay ti Tjokotjoko.
S.TRANSL: Tjukutjuku became pregnant.

S.FORM: makalimał a vunglanglay; puałak tu uqałay tu ti Kułełułełu.
makalimalj a vonglanglay; poaljak to oqaljay to ti Koljeljoljeljo.
S.TRANSL: She was pregnant for five days, and bore a son called Kułełułełu.

S.FORM: "aku a puałak a paqeteleng a neka nu tsekeł?
"ako a poaljak a paqeteleng a neka no cekelj?
S.TRANSL: “Why has she had a child on the side without being married?

S.FORM: kałavaru a temaqałan tuki tima a navenunglay."
kaljavaro a temaqaljan toki tima a navenonglay."
S.TRANSL: All the village must find out who made her pregnant.”

S.FORM: manu neka.
mano neka.
S.TRANSL: But noone was found.

S.FORM: "kełu," ayain ti Pułałułałuyan a se Łinasalas.
"keljo," ayain ti Poljaljoljaljoyan a se Ljinasalas.
S.TRANSL: Then Pułałułałuyan of Łinasalas was asked to come.

S.FORM: manu mangtjez ti Pułałułałuyan.
mano mangtjez ti Poljaljoljaljoyan.
S.TRANSL: So he came.

S.FORM: "pai, ła kina, avan tsu a ku kama."
"pai, lja kina, avan co a ko kama."
S.TRANSL: (The child said:) “Now, mother, this is my father.”

S.FORM: saka "iya, manu avan tsu a kama," aya a temaqałan.
saka "iya, mano avan co a kama," aya a temaqaljan.
S.TRANSL: So all the village said: “Well, so this is the father!”

S.FORM: sa pavay anga sakamaya tua sinilisi, sa pareputsekeł anga sakamaya.
sa pavay anga sakamaya toa sinilisi, sa parepocekelj anga sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: So he gave the bride-price, and they finished by getting married.

S.FORM: saka amin a kai.
saka amin a kai.
S.TRANSL: That’s the end of the story.
